newsitem.title: USA: ASARCO hunts gold among snakes and spiders.
newsitem.headline: ASARCO hunts gold among snakes and spiders.

text.p: ASARCO's probe for gold in French Guyana is proving to be a challenge for geologists who, drenched in sixteen feet of annual rainfall, wade through mud and snakes as part of their daily quest, analysts were told Friday.
"This is not easy country to explore," ASARCO's chairman, president and chief executive, Richard de J Osborne said.
"Water, mud, snakes and spiders are part of the exploration geologists' daily struggle," Osborne added.
Analysts questioned why ASARCO spent most of its $26.5 million exploration budget last year on tracking down yellow metal in the South American country.

ASARCO has only been seriously drilling in French Guyana for about a year. "We are not in a position to announce any reserves or any resources," Osborne said. "I hope that in 12 months we will have something more positive or at least more definitive to announce."
There has been placer or stream bed mining in the country for years and ASARCO was trying to find the source of the placer deposits, Osborne said.
ASARCO will spend a major portion of its exploration budget in French Guyana again this year.
"Gold is a wonderful way of creating value," Osborne said.
